title: Eliphaz’s Counsel
shortSummary: In Job chapter 4, Eliphaz the Temanite responds to Job’s suffering by reminding him of the principle that the innocent do not perish and the wicked reap what they sow. He shares a troubling vision that emphasizes human frailty before God’s justice, urging Job to consider his ways and repent if necessary.
timeline: c. 2000-1800 BC - Patriarchal Period, during the lifetime of Job

keyCharacters.name: Eliphaz the Temanite
keyCharacters.description: One of Job’s three friends who speaks first, offering counsel based on his own experience and a divine vision, emphasizing retributive justice.

keyCharacters.name: Job
keyCharacters.description: The central figure suffering great loss and affliction, whom Eliphaz addresses and challenges in this chapter.

definitions.definition: A descendant of Esau, known for wisdom and often associated with Edomite territory; Eliphaz’s tribal or regional identity.
To attempt or try; here it means to attempt to speak or commune with Job.
An agricultural metaphor meaning to commit sin or evil deeds, implying that one will reap corresponding consequences.
A metaphor for human bodies, emphasizing human frailty and mortality.

outline.heading: Eliphaz’s Introduction and Appeal to Speak
outline.description: Eliphaz opens by asking permission to speak and acknowledges Job’s past role in strengthening others, setting a respectful tone before addressing Job’s current plight.

outline.heading: The Principle of Retribution and Righteousness
outline.description: Eliphaz asserts the traditional belief that the innocent do not perish and that those who sow wickedness reap destruction, illustrated through vivid imagery of lions and divine judgment.

outline.heading: Eliphaz’s Vision and Divine Warning
outline.description: Eliphaz recounts a terrifying vision in the night where a voice questions human righteousness compared to God’s holiness, emphasizing human frailty and the folly of trusting in mortal strength.

application: Recognize that suffering is not always without cause and examine your life for any hidden sin that may need repentance.
Trust in God’s justice and sovereignty, remembering that He is holy and humans are frail and fallible.
Encourage others with your words as Job once did, but also be willing to receive correction in humility.
Seek God’s wisdom through prayer and Scripture when facing trials, rather than relying solely on human reasoning.

keyVerses.text: Remember, I pray thee, who ever perished, being innocent? or where were the righteous cut off?
keyVerses.significance: This verse encapsulates Eliphaz’s argument that innocence is preserved by God, challenging Job to consider the cause of his suffering.

keyVerses.text: Shall mortal man be more just than God? shall a man be more pure than his maker?
keyVerses.significance: A powerful reminder of God’s absolute holiness compared to human imperfection, underscoring the need for humility.

keyVerses.text: How much less in them that dwell in houses of clay, whose foundation is in the dust, which are crushed before the moth?
keyVerses.significance: This metaphor highlights human frailty and mortality, emphasizing that humans cannot compare to God’s power and wisdom.
